quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Yale and Revolution
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, pioneer, theory. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What is/are the color/colors of the socialist flag?
Mikhail Bakunin, an 1800s socialist, was also the father of what other ideology?
Which socialist theorist advocated permanent revolution, arguing that a socialist state could only prosper if the capitalist states that influenced it also became socialist.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leon Trotsky

questions.question: Academy Award-winning actress Jodie Foster graduated magna cum laude from Yale University, earning a B.A. in this subject.

Karl Marx, a teacher of socialism, said that a socialist state was possible because the lower classes were being brought together from distant farms into large cities. What revolution made this possible?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Industrial Revolution

questions.question: Juan Trippe was an airline entrepreneur and pioneer who graduated from Yale in 1921. Who portrayed him in Martin Scorseses movie The Aviator?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alec Baldwin

questions.question: Wyoming has never elected a female governor.
Which of these US Presidents did not attend Yale University?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy

questions.question: In 1918, after a revolution to overthrow an autocratic ruler, this country experienced a small civil war in which socialists defeated communists.
What theory proposed socialism in one country?
In 1930, this Yale graduate, author of It Cant Happen Here, became the first American to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sinclair Lewis

questions.question: This painter, telegraph pioneer and inventor graduated from Yale in 1810.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Samuel Morse

questions.question: What Yale graduate received Pulitzer Prizes for the novel The Bridge of San Luis Rey and the play Our Town?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thornton Wilder

questions.question: What government, formed in 1871, was referred to by Marx and Engels as the first ever socialist state?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Paris Commune

questions.question: What minor league baseball team moved to Casper, Wyoming in 2001?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Casper Ghosts

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Case and School
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, commemorate. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Vicente Fernandez, Pedro Infante, Javier Solis, and Lola Beltran are representatives of this traditional, Mexican genre of music.
The case of Epperson v. State of Arkansas in 1968 dealt primarily with what?

options.text: Whether U.S.  state tests may be given to home school children
Whether literacy tests are required for advancement into junior high school
Whether U.S. states must require a balance of creationism and evolution
Whether U.S. states could not forbid the teaching of evolution

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Whether U.S. states could not forbid the teaching of evolution

questions.question: This actor, who earned an MFA from Yale School of Drama, is famous for his long-running roles on Law  Order and Sex and the City.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chris Noth

questions.question: This case came before the court of appeals of New York in 1967 and stated that school officials may be obligated to inspect school lockers. It determined that the school has parents’ locus rights at the school, which gives them the right to inspect lockers of students in the absence of their parents.

options.text: Brooks v. East Chambers High School

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: People v. Overton

questions.question: Who assumed office as President of Mexico on December 2006?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Felipe Calderon

questions.question: In 1982, justice William J. Brennan delivered the U.S. Supreme Courts opinion on this case that stated undocumented children of alien parents cannot be denied a public education. It stemmed from a case in Texas.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Plyler v. Doe

questions.question: Although it was recognized on September 27, 1821, the Independence of Mexico from Spain was declared on September 16, 1810 by this priest.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla

questions.question: Which of these notable Yale graduates is not correctly matched with the movie they directed?

options.text: Home for the Holidays - Jodie Foster

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Roy Hill - Gentlemans Agreement

questions.question: In 1975 Mexicos capital city hosted the XIX Olympic Games.
What Yale graduate is credited with creating the first time bomb and first submarine ever used in combat?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: David Bushell

questions.question: What are the two animals featured on the Mexican flag?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Eagle and Snake

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered a Mexican dish?
In 1879, which U.S. Supreme Court case invoked the famous dictum of Jefferson, calling for the erection of a wall of separation between church and state?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Reynolds v. United States

questions.question: Besides being Yale graduates, what else do the following actors have in common: Paul Newman, Meryl Streep, Jennifer Connelly?

options.text: They all graduated magna cum laude.
They are all Academy Award winners.
They all graduated with a degree in literature.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They are all Academy Award winners.

questions.question: What does Cinco de Mayo (May 5th) commemorate in Mexican culture?

options.text: A Mexican battle victory over the British
A Mexican battle victory over the French

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Mexican battle victory over the French

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Bus and Queens
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, dealt, title. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What is the name of the capital and largest city of France?
According to the 2006 American Community Survey, Queens has the largest Asian American population outside of the western U.S.
Which of these countries does not share a border with Metropolitan France, i.e. France in Western Europe?
What is the official language spoken within the territory of the French Republic?
What two major airports is Queens home to?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy and LaGuardia

questions.question: What is the title of the national anthem of the French Republic?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Song of Marseille

questions.question: In this case Bobby Wayne Blair sustained permanent injury to his right eye when riding on a bus on his way to school from an object thrown by another student on the bus. The case stated that the bus driver was negligent in properly supervising the bus and the activities on that bus.

options.text: Ponton v. Newport News School Board
Albers v. Independent School District No. 302 of Lewis County
Blair v. Board of Education of Sherburne-Earlville Central School

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Blair v. Board of Education of Sherburne-Earlville Central School

questions.question: If each NY borough was an independent city, Queens would be among the 10 most populous cities in the U.S.
The 1974 U.S. Supreme Court case in Iowa, Erb v. Iowa State Board of Education, dealt with what?

options.text: Reduction in force must be in good faith
A teachers adultery is no reason to revoke license

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A teachers adultery is no reason to revoke license

questions.question: What is the most popular religion in France according to official data from 2007?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roman Catholicism

questions.question: When Janet Cooper wore white clothes and a white turban to school to teach her sixth grade class, she also wrote a letter to the staff of the school stating that she would wear the turban as part of her religious practice. When she refused to NOT wear the garments, she was suspended and her certificate was revoked. In this case the court found that a tenured teacher could have their certificate revoked for violating state statute by wearing religious garb in school.

options.text: Cooper v. Fargo Public School District

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cooper v. Eugene School District

questions.question: Which of these colors is not present on the national flag of the French Republic?
Which of the following movies was filmed in Queens?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What is the name of the river that flows through the capital city of France?
This court case dealt with a Title IX issue of the education amendments of 1972. It protects employees against gender discrimination in educational institutions.

options.text: North Haven v. Board of Education v. Bell

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: North Haven v. Board of Education v. Bell

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Government and Law
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, massachusetts, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was the last Chief of the Comanches?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Quannah Parker

questions.question: Which of these popular French fashion designers was not born in France?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yves Saint Laurent

questions.question: What are Navajo rugs really made from?
What is the meaning of the Native American expression Dine’tah?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Navajo Land

questions.question: From which group of Native Americans do we get the word tipi?
Who was Wilma Mankiller?

options.text: The first Native American to be elected to the US Congress
The first female Native American to be director of UNESCO
The first female Principal Chief of the Cherokee
The first female Native American to be a US Army General

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The first female Principal Chief of the Cherokee

questions.question: In what year did the US Government pass a law making the government responsible for preserving the languages of indigenous peoples of the USA?
What do we call the houses built by the Piute people?
What type of meal is the traditional French dish called Bouillabaisse?
How many different tribal governments are recognized by the US government?
What is the Navajo word for non-Native Americans?
Which Native American group lived in hogans?
In May, 2005 the Massachusetts state government repealed a law involving Native Americans. What did the original law ban?

options.text: Native Americans teaching their own languages
Native Americans voting in state elections

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Native Americans entering Boston

questions.question: What do we call the dwellings built by the Pawnees?
What is the name of the woman that has been the symbol of France for centuries?

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Country and Countries
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, colonies, country. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This landlocked African country is one of the 10 poorest countries in the world. Its capital, Bujumbura, is located on Lake Tanganyika.
This land-locked country is bordered on 3 sides by the Republic of South Africa, and on the east by Mozambique. It has the highest HIV/AIDS prevalence in the world at 39% according to 2006 estimates.
In the late 1800s, the European nations scrambled to acquire colonies in Africa. Which of the following did NOT become a colony of a European country?
How many different languages are spoken in Africa?
In all of the following countries except one, Muslims comprise more than 85% of the population. Which of the following countries is NOT primarily Muslim?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Central African Republic

questions.question: What year did the U.S. Supreme Court install its first photocopy machine?
This country in the Indian Ocean, comprising some 115 islands, is officially considered an African country.
Which list includes the five native American tribes regarded by Early Europeans as “civilized?

options.text: Seminole, Choctaw, Chickasaw, Cherokee, and Creek
Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Iroquois
Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Cree
Cherokee, Choctaw, Creek, Chirokawa, and Cree

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Seminole, Choctaw, Chickasaw, Cherokee, and Creek

questions.question: How many African countries are there?
The click languages of Africa (also known as the Khoisan languages) are spoken in all of the following countries except one. In which of these countries is a click language NOT widely spoken?
What year was the U.S. Supreme Courts website created?
Which African country has the highest GDP (gross domestic product) according to 2008 estimates?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: South Africa

questions.question: Which famous Native American ballerina has been honored for her great achievements?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maria Tallchief

questions.question: What part did President Andrew Jackson have in destroying Native American life?

options.text: He had the Indian Removal Act of 1830 passed.
He led the attacks on the homes of the Five Civilized Tribes between 1819 and 1827.
After the Battle of New Orleans, Jackson led an attack on the Natchez, Seminole, and Red Bird tribes.
Under his presidency, the lands of the Dakota (Sioux), Cheyenne, and Arapajo were taken over by the US government.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He had the Indian Removal Act of 1830 passed.

questions.question: The African Union is a confederation of all African countries except one. Which is the only African country that is NOT a member of the African Union?

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Oklahoma and Case
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, crawford, land. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: According to a census done in the 1990s, Oklahoma is 2nd to what state in total Native American population?
Legendary actress Joan Crawford once lived in Oklahoma.
Democrat Brad Henry became Governor of Oklahoma in November 2002.
The Plessy v. Ferguson U.S. Supreme Court case (1896) dealt with a crime on a riverboat in Louisiana.
In 2005 Oklahoma ranked 2nd in natural gas production in the United States.
Hearings in camera allow for television or other news related cameras to be present in the U.S. court during the hearing.
In the U.S. Supreme Court system, what does the term rule of four mean?

options.text: At least four justices must be present, robed and seated to in order to hear a case.
The Court will hear cases that a substantial minority of justices regards as important.
Four lawyers must be present when a case is argued.
There can be no less than four arguments pertaining to any one case.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Court will hear cases that a substantial minority of justices regards as important.

questions.question: Who was the second woman to be appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

questions.question: The first African-American owned bank in America was established in Boley, Oklahoma.
The Marbury v. Madison case (1803) was the first U.S. Supreme Court case to apply the emergent doctrine of judicial review to a congressional statute.
Where was the first parking meter installed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oklahoma City

questions.question: The Sixth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution does not guarantee the right to which of the following?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A trial in a courtroom

questions.question: The Dred Scott case (Scott v. Sandford, 1857) is an infamous U.S. Supreme Court case involving which of the following?
Oklahoma City was founded during the Land Run of 1891.
What is the original meaning of the term Slip Opinion as applied to the U.S. Supreme Court?

options.text: An opinion that has later been overturned after careful review
Opinions sent to the printer on the same day they are made
Opinions made by the justices for their own private records
The overall opinion of the garments that the justices wear under their robes

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Opinions sent to the printer on the same day they are made
